name: Carolina Agurto Gangas
sub_title: FONDECYT Postdoctoral fellow at Universidad de Chile

home.description: I am an ESO-Comité Mixto postdoctoral researcher in the Astronomy Department at Universidad de Chile. I obtained my B.Sc. in Physics (2012) and M.Sc. in Astrophysics (2015) degrees from Universidad de Valparaíso, Chile. I completed my doctoral degree in 2020 at Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München. My main research interests focus on the early stages of protoplanetary disks, investigating both the characterization of the dusty envelope and the processes of dust growth within the disk by using sub-mm and mm wavelengths. Currently, I'm working in the gas and dust caracterization of the ALMA Large Programm AGE-PRO (the ALMA survey of Gas Evolution in PROtoplanetary disks).

papers.abstract: Disks and envelopes around protostars play a fundamental role in the process of planet formation, since they contain the ingredients which could be used later to form planets (Testi, et al. 2014, Protostars and Planets VI, 339). Thanks to detailed studies on protoplanetary disks such as: HL Tau (Partnership, et al. 2015, ApJL, 808, 1), it is now well established that Class II objects have already dust grains of millimeters sizes. However, it is not yet clear at which stage of the star and planet formation process dust grains start to efficiently coagulate and evolve from micrometer dust size particles to macroscopic dimensions.

Dust continuum emission in the millimeter wavelengths allow us to test the presence of mm-sized dust grains. This is due to the fact that at these wavelengths the emission is mostly optically thin. The variation in the flux between different frequencies is a good proxy for the spectral index β which is related to the maximum grain size. Values of β ∼ 1 indicate that mm sized particles have been formed, while values around β ∼ 1.7 represent the sizes of ISM particle (Natta et al., 2007; Testi et al., 2014). Classical protoplanetary disks (around Class II objects) present clear signs of dust coagulation (Testi et al., 2014, and references therein). Toward pre-stellar cores the evidence is less clear: large (micrometer) grains have been found (Pagani et al., 2011), but this has been recently challenged (Jones et al., 2016).

In my PhD project, we plan to explore grain growth by measuring β index in Class I protostars at different wavelenghts, which will allow us to bridge the gap between the well studied Class II objects and the earlier stage. We propose a multiwavelength study of Class I protoplanetary disks in different star forming regions, in order to constrain the grain sizes in disk as well in the inner and outer region of envelopes. With the capabilities of ALMA, SMA and NOEMA this will be the first unbiased study of grain growth in Class I protostars with the highest angular resolution and sensitivity ever seen.
Here you can find links to useful raditiave transfer and interferometric data fitting tools
You can check out my full record of authored and co-authored publications on

Star Tres was founded in 2013 by Javiera Rey, Karina Rojas and myself during our Bachelor (Universidad de Valparaíso). Star Tres is a digital initiative composed by a website, social media, and a YouTube channel. Our main goal is to be a reliable source of information with simple and engaging content for all astronomy-lover public. We also advocate gender equality in STEM and critical thinking in our society.
All of our content is in Spanish, to fill the lack of Latin American astronomy outreach initiatives on internet.

projects.title: AGE-PRO
projects.description: The ALMA Large Program AGE-PRO focuses on the gas and dust characterization in protoplanetary disks to study their evolution and the initial conditions for planet formation.

projects.title: Class I Protostars
projects.description: A multiwavelength study of Class I protoplanetary disks in various star-forming regions to investigate grain growth and the physical conditions in early-stage protostars.

projects.title: SiDE (SimpleDiskEnvFit)
projects.description: A radiative transfer and interferometric data fitting tool for analyzing protoplanetary disks and their environments.

projects.title: Star Tres
projects.description: A digital initiative for astronomy outreach, aimed at providing reliable and engaging content in Spanish, promoting gender equality in STEM, and fostering critical thinking.

papers.abstract: Star Tres was founded in 2013 by Javiera Rey, Karina Rojas, and myself during our Bachelor studies (Universidad de Valparaíso). Star Tres is a digital initiative composed of a website, social media, and a YouTube channel. Our main goal is to be a reliable source of information with simple and engaging content for all astronomy-lovers. We also advocate for gender equality in STEM and critical thinking in our society.
All of our content is in Spanish, to fill the lack of Latin American astronomy outreach initiatives on the internet.

name: Carolina Agurto Gangas
sub_title: FONDECYT Postdoctoral fellow at Universidad de Chile

home.description: I am an ESO-Comité Mixto postdoctoral researcher in the Astronomy Department at Universidad de Chile. My main research interests focus on the early stages of protoplanetary disks, investigating both the characterization of the dusty envelope and the processes of dust growth within the disk by using sub-mm and mm wavelengths. Currently, I'm working on the gas and dust characterization of the ALMA Large Program AGE-PRO (the ALMA survey of Gas Evolution in PROtoplanetary disks).

papers.abstract:
Disks and envelopes around protostars play a fundamental role in the process of planet formation, since they contain the ingredients which could be used later to form planets (Testi et al. 2014, Protostars and Planets VI, 339).

- Thanks to detailed studies on protoplanetary disks such as HL Tau (Partnership et al. 2015, ApJL, 808, 1), it is now well established that Class II objects have already dust grains of millimeter sizes.
- However, it is not yet clear at which stage of the star and planet formation process dust grains start to efficiently coagulate and evolve from micrometer dust size particles to macroscopic dimensions.

Dust continuum emission in the millimeter wavelengths allows us to test the presence of mm-sized dust grains. This is due to the fact that at these wavelengths the emission is mostly optically thin.

- The variation in the flux between different frequencies is a good proxy for the spectral index β, which is related to the maximum grain size.
- Values of β ∼ 1 indicate that mm-sized particles have been formed, while values around β ∼ 1.7 represent the sizes of ISM particles (Natta et al., 2007; Testi et al., 2014).
- Classical protoplanetary disks (around Class II objects) present clear signs of dust coagulation (Testi et al., 2014, and references therein).
- Toward pre-stellar cores, the evidence is less clear: large (micrometer) grains have been found (Pagani et al., 2011), but this has been recently challenged (Jones et al., 2016).
